description: Experts say to look beyond spa days. Instead, wellness comes from accessible and even free habits. Read more at straitstimes.com.
title: Why your ideas about ‘wellness’ and ‘self-care’ are probably wrong
title_page: Why your ideas about ‘wellness’ and ‘self-care’ are probably wrong | The Straits Times
maintext:
SINGAPORE – What does “wellness” mean to you? Massages, manicures and mindfully drinking tea?
Images of such activities often accompany “wellness” content on social media. Products such as aromatic oils and services from exercise classes to oxygen therapy anchor a global wellness industry, which was worth US$5.6 trillion (S$7.6 trillion) in 2022, according to Global Wellness Institute.
